title: 103_s1208
content: The Act is titled the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government units before the National Park Service took over preservation duties. The National Park Service took over preservation duties for historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall. Financial constraints have hindered the government from meeting the capital needs of these sites, prompting the suggestion to mint a commemorative coin to fund their maintenance and preservation. The government is considering minting a commemorative coin to fund the maintenance and preservation of historic buildings in Philadelphia. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The design will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, with inscriptions including the year "1994" and various patriotic phrases. These coins will be legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility for a period of up to one year after enactment. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount. A surcharge of $7 per coin is required for all sales. Additionally, there is a general waiver of procurement regulations. General waiver of procurement regulations for goods or services necessary for the Act's provisions. Compliance with equal employment opportunity laws is still required for contracts under this Act. Distribution of surcharges is also addressed. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. 50% of surcharges from coin sales go to the Treasury to reduce national debt, and 50% goes to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for park improvements. SEC. 10. AUDITS. SEC. 10. AUDITS. The Comptroller General can examine Independence Hall Preservation Fund's records related to section 9 expenditures. SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND. Coins issued are subject to section 5134 of title 31, US Code for the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 11. The coins issued under this Act are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government and require adequate security for payment before issuing coins.
